column1: Alport syndrome is an inherited disorder that damages the tiny blood vessels in the kidneys.
Alport syndrome is an inherited form of kidney inflammation (nephritis).
It is caused by a mutation in a gene for a protein in the connective tissue, called collagen.
Women can pass the gene for the disorder to their children, even if they have no symptoms.

Signs include: - Changes to the eye, including the fundus (back inner part of the eye), cataracts, or bulging of the lens (lenticonus) - High blood pressure The following tests may be done: - Audiometry - BUN and serum creatinine - Complete blood count - Renal biopsy - Urinalysis
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers can control blood pressure and slow the rate at which the disease gets worse.
Surgery to repair cataracts (cataract extraction) or a bulging of the lens in the eye may be needed.
Rarely, women will have high blood pressure, swelling, and nerve deafness as a complication of pregnancy.

Call for an appointment with your health care provider if: - You have symptoms of Alport syndrome - You have a family history of Alport syndrome and you are planning to have children - Your urine output decreases or stops or you see blood in your urine (this may be a symptom of chronic kidney disease)
